components.description:
A globe, showing the continents of Europe and Africa in green against blue ocean.

May be used to represent various content concerning the European, African, and Atlantic regions. May also be used to represent Earth and international affairs more generally.

See also üåé Globe Showing Americas and üåè Globe Showing Asia-Australia.
components.title: Earth Globe Europe-Africa

title: Earth Globe Europe-Africa

version.description:
Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.

Some characters in prior versions of Unicode were retroactively updated to provide an emoji presentation. This release was the first to introduce new characters for the sole purpose of compatability with emojis being used in Japan.

emoji_net_data.category: Miscellaneous Symbols And Pictographs -> Globe symbols
emoji_net_data.definition: The world, showing Europe and Africa. Globe Showing Europe-Africa was approved as part of Unicode 6.0 in 2010 under the name ‚ÄúEarth Globe Eu http://emojipedia.org/earth-globe-europe-africa/
emoji_net_data.name: globe showing Europe-Africa

bn:00105294a: Between or among nations; pertaining to the intercourse of nations; participated in by two or more nations; common to, or affecting, two or more nations.
Concerning or belonging to at least two nations.
Concerning or belonging to all or at least two or more nations

bn:00103624a: Concerning all parts of the world.
Pertaining to an entire document, file, or program rather than to a restricted segment of it.
Of, or relating to the whole Earth; global.
Involving the entire earth; not limited or provincial in scope.
Involving the entire earth; not limited or provincial in scope

bn:00087454v: To connect electrically to the earth.

bn:00088912v: Change location; move, travel, or proceed, also metaphorically
To change (from one value to another).
To move or travel (from one location to another).
To change the location of an object.
To transfer a file from one location to another. After the file is transferred, there is only one copy of the file, in the new location.
To move an object one pixel at a time.

bn:13772895v: To introduce into the world; to bear (eg a child) -->

bn:00001816n: The second largest of the continents, on the Mediterranean in the north, the Atlantic in the west, and the Red Sea, Gulf of Aden, and Indian Ocean in the east.
The continent that is south of Europe, east of the Atlantic Ocean, west of the Indian Ocean and north of Antarctica. It holds the following countries:
The second largest continent; located to the south of Europe and bordered to the west by the South Atlantic and to the east by the Indian Ocean
From a Eurocentric point of view.
Africa is the world's second-largest and second-most-populous continent.

bn:03086073n: International mostly means something involving more than a single country.

bn:00029424n: The third planet (counted from the center) of our solar system.
Earth is the third planet from the Sun and is the largest of the terrestrial planets in the Solar System, in both diameter and mass.
The 3rd planet from the sun; the planet we live on
The third planet from the Sun

Earth, also known as the world, Terra, or Gaia, is the third planet from the Sun, the densest planet in the Solar System, the largest of the Solar System's four terrestrial planets, and the only celestial body known to accommodate life.
Third planet closest to the Sun in the Solar System
The third planet in order from the Sun, upon which humans live. Represented in astronomy and astrology by ? and ?.

bn:00031896n: Europe is a continent that comprises the westernmost peninsula of Eurasia.
Europe is one of the traditional seven political continents, and a peninsular sub-continent of the geographic continent Eurasia.
The 2nd smallest continent (actually a vast peninsula of Eurasia); the British use `Europe' to refer to all of the continent except the British Isles
The second smallest continent, forming the Western extension of Eurasia: the border with Asia runs from the Urals to the Caspian and the Black Sea.
